html:
A new report from McKinsey dropped last week that made me sit up and take notice. Not because the wellness industry is booming (we knew that), but because of what the data reveals about where it’s failing.

Americans are spending more than $500 billion annually on wellness products and services. Gen Z and millennials are driving 41% of that spending despite being just 36% of the adult population. People are buying everything from functional nutrition to boutique fitness classes to longevity supplements.

But here’s the kicker: consumers report that many of their wellness needs remain unmet. Particularly in mental health, cognitive health, and motivation.

As someone who’s spent a decade designing behavioral interventions for health apps, I read this and saw something McKinsey didn’t explicitly call out. This isn’t just a market opportunity. It’s a behavior change problem disguised as a market research report.

A motivation crisis hidden in the data
